title: Possible Memory Leak (or something similar?)
body:
I'm not sure what's going on, but when I first open the client and play a few games everything runs smoothly, but as the hours go by it just gets slower and slower to the point where there's almost a full second lag between my messages being typed and appearing on the screen, or clicking on a tab and the tab showing up. Closing and restarting the client seems to fix the issue temporarily.

I checked the league processes in task manager and none of them seemed to be using what I would consider an abnormal amount of memory for a 2d game client (I'm just assuming that anything >1.5GB is abnormal) so I'm not sure what's going on exactly.

replies.body: Yep, been happening to everyone THIS CLIENT IS SO FUCKED

100% the case of memory leak. 

I played about 8 games of poro king in a row last night. After playing for a while, I left the post match screen on in the background while browsing some online forums and youtube. When I went to close the client and shutdown my computer before I went to bed everything just froze. My entire computer froze from the client. It took 30 seconds for the Windows task manager to open when it normally takes one second. The league client was the only program open at the time.  Even after after the client was closed my computer took much much longer than usual to process normal tasks and to shutdown.

It's weird...I left the client open over night once (rather recently), playing the occational game. However, the client got gradually slower and slower and slower.
https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/bug-report/km67EyZE-huge-fps-drops-in-game-in-both-sr-and-tft-since-patch-922-came-out?comment=0004

...until it finally crashed. No warning, no unresponding application error, it just shut itself down and automatically restarted.

Here's the weird part: It didn't take more RAM than usual and the CPU load was negligible. So what the hell actually happened with the client, I have no idea. 
Never happened to me before (on prior crashes, it at least gives an error - this time, nothing!), and never happened since.

I have had a proper memory leak though, but that was with Firefox (v.69): 2 tabs open (this was a replicable error), and upon opening any image on a specific web page (reputable webshop), the RAM counter started. 

Didn't catch it the first time, until I was suddenly told I didn't have enough RAM to open even a small .jpg image in my editing software. And found Firefox taking 26 GB RAM (of 32).

Oh yeah. Depending on circumstances, that is called "siblings" or "parents".

But there are sometimes unexplainable "black holes" in a connection that just swallows up bandwidth (I am serious here btw.). They are rare, but for us in the know, we know of them. But we sadly cannot explain them.
Lol I mean like, is it possible for something in a program to cause it to use progressively more and more bandwidth for routine communications to the point where it lags itself out?

> [{quoted}](name=shunpo script,realm=NA,application-id=LqLKtMpN,discussion-id=fTQT6jG9,comment-id=0009000000000000,timestamp=2020-01-01T12:26:34.919+0000)
>
> I mean like, is it possible for something in a program to cause it to use progressively more and more bandwidth for routine communications to the point where it lags itself out?

_Whenever someone says "lol" in a sentence, I cannot take them seriously..._

Short answer: No.

Not on its own, but bandwidth usage is determined by the number of simultaneous connections. But that's really just a case in peer-to-peer software (.torrenting being the most notable). Or using multiple online services at the same time, like browsing, streaming and downloading at the same time.

The higher number of connections, the more bandwidth will be consumed. The only limiting factor here is your connection speed or inadequate hardware (i.e. crappy router) that will eventually lock up because it can't handle all the simultaneous connection requests.

Too many connection requests with a limited connection speed (like ADSL), and you'll shortly feel lag ingame. Other exceptions would be like a DDOS attack, where thousands of ping requests are made at the same time (instead of like a handful), to deliberately overload a server or networking unit.
